intro: Crocodeilanthe rictoria, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that primarily grows on the branches of tropical trees. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and is characterized by its dense, leafy foliage and yellowish-green berries. The plant lacks true roots and absorbs nutrients through haustoria that penetrate into the host's vascular system. It is typically found in humid, tropical regions of Southeast Asia. Its unique appearance and parasitic nature make it an interesting subject in botanical studies.
